text.content:
Age: 56  GENDER: FEMALE   RACE: WHITE 
MARITAL STATUS:  Divorced.

 

                           CLINICAL HISTORY

PRESENTING CHIEF COMPLAINT: 
Depression, thoughts of suicide


HISTORY OF CURRENT ILLNESS:
depression successfully treated in primary care for past 5 years with anti-
depressant.  Admitted from ER to Psychiatry on February 2nd for suicideal 
ideation. 
Adverse drug reactions to previous anti-depresant meds, Fluoxetine (severe 
anxiety) and Citalopram (severe anxiety.)  Currently on venlafaxine 75mg BID 
which had been effective the past few years. 


Current neurovegetative symptoms:
  Mood: sad
  Sleep:  6+ hrs per night.  goal 8 hours.
  Interests:  limited interest in her normal activities
  Energy:  still a little low.  need TSH
  Guilty/Worthless Thoughts:  mildy intrusive thoughts of worthlessness since 
divorce
  Concentration:  ok
  Appetite:  ok
  Psychomotor:  none
  SI:  denies
  Hopeless Thoughts:  occasional
  Helpless Thoughts:  occasional

    PHQ-9
      A PHQ-9 screen was performed. The score was 6 which is suggestive of
          mild depression.

          1. Little interest or pleasure in doing things
          Several days

          2. Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless
          Several days

          3. Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much
          Several days

          4. Feeling tired or having little energy
          Several days

          5. Poor appetite or overeating
          Several days

          6. Feeling bad about yourself or that you are a failure or have
          let yourself or your family down
          Not at all

          7. Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the
          newspaper or watching television
          Not at all

          8. Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have
          noticed. Or the opposite being so fidgety or restless that you
          have been moving around a lot more than usual
          Not at all

          9. Thoughts that you would be better off dead or of hurting
          yourself in some way
          Several days

          10. If you checked off any problems, how DIFFICULT have these
          problems made it for you to do your work, take care of things at
          home or get along with other people?
          Somewhat difficult


PTSD Symptoms:
  Hyperarousal:  none
  Avoidance/Numbing:  none
  Re-experiencing:  none
  Nightmares:  none

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY: 
Depression treated in PC only.


HISTORY OF SUICIDAL ACTS AND SELF-HARM: 
None
SUPPLEMENTAL RISK ASSESSMENT:
                        RISK ASSESSMENT
SECTION I - Current Risk of Self/Others:

  Yes - Does Pt. have SI or making suicidal threats?
   No  - Does Pt. have HI or making homicidal threats?
   No  - Does Pt. have access to weapons?
  Yes - Does Pt. have access to lethal doses of medications?
If answers to the above are NO, then go to Section II, otherwise:

   No  - Is the ideation chronic?
  Yes - Does Pt. have specific plan?
  Yes - Does ideation involve serious/lethal intent?
   No  - Is there delusional/hallucinatory content?

If yes to any of the above, please explain with detail:
prior to hospitalization, patient had a specific plans for suicide - overdose of 
prescription medications.


_____________________________________________________________________
SECTION II - History of Suicidal / Homicidal Ideation / Behavior

  Yes - Is there a history of suicidal/self-injuring ideation/
        behavior?
   No  - Is there a history of homicidal/assaultive ideation/
        behavior?
   No  - Is there a history of serious physical harm to self/
        others while in an intensive tx. setting?

If yes to any of the above, please explain with detail:
SI only


_____________________________________________________________________
SECTION III - Accuracy of reports and history of risk:

   No  - Is there any evidence or concern that the pt. or others
        may be concealing or denying current or past suicide /
        homicidal / assaultive - ideation/behaviors?

If yes, please explain with detail:


_____________________________________________________________________
SECTION IV - Suicide & Homicide/violence risk factors additional to 
sections I-III.
SUICIDE RISK FACTORS:
Younger than 19 OR older 45 years
Single, widowed, divorced, separated
Severe problems with significant others
Major depression
Organized plan w/ lethal intent
Hopelessness
HOMICIDE/VIOLENCE RISK FACTORS:
COMMENTS
no risk factors for violence towards others

_____________________________________________________________________
SUMMARY EVALUATION OF RISK OF SUICIDE / HOMICIDE / ASSAULTIVE BEHAVIOR:

Rank your conclusion regarding this patient's SUICIDAL risk:
Low

Rank your conclusion regarding this patient's HOMICIDAL / ASSAULTIVE risk:
Low

Comments:
Currently, low risk of suicide due to excellent social support from family, 
friends, 
church.

HISTORY OF VIOLENCE/ASSAULTING OTHERS/LEGAL PROBLEMS:
None

SUBSTANCE USE HISTORY: 
rare alcohol.  denies illicit drugs



MENTAL ILLNESS AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE IN FAMILY MEMBERS: 
brother, mother with depression


PSYCHOSOCIAL HISTORY: 
 a) Childhood/Developmental History: n/a


 b) Adult Relationship History: divorced, patient is anxious whne speaking to 
ex-husband about child care related 
issues


 c) Sexual History:
    AVIVAPATIENT,SIX's sexual orientation is Heterosexual.
    Age of first sexual experience: 22
    Estimate of total number of past sexual partners:  3
    AVIVAPATIENT,SIX has never engaged in high risk sexual behavior.
    Explain:    denies
    Additional comments: 
 

 d) Current significant family and/or peer group relationships: 
3 adult children, 2 teenagers living at home. 


 e) Financial Status, Housing, Employment, Leisure Time Issues: works as a 
administrtive assistant at a law firm

 
 f) Religious/Spiritual or Cultural Issues that might influence treatment: 
active in church, supportive social structure


 g) Relevant community resources accessed by patient:
None 

MILITARY HISTORY:
     Service Entry Date: 6/1975
Service Separation Date: 9/1995
      Branch of Service: Army
           Purple Heart: No 

NSC VETERAN

                          MEDICAL INFORMATION


 a) CURRENT MEDICAL PROBLEMS: 
Computerized Problem List is the source for the following: 
 
1. Obesity, Onset 00/00/04                            05/30/12  AVIVAUSER,THIRT
2. Hyperlipidemia                                     09/22/09  PROVIDER,ONE 
3. Diabetes Mellitus Type II or unspecified, Onset    05/10/12  PROVIDER,ONE 
00/00/05 
     Adequate control on oral medications.
     Goal to lose 50 pounds in 1 year.
4. Osteopenia, Onset 00/00/08                         11/19/08  PROVIDER,ONE 
5. Postsurgical hypothyroidism, Onset 00/00/02        05/10/12  PROVIDER,ONE 
     Complete thryoidectomy for thyroid cancer in 2002.
6. Depression, Onset 00/00/08                         11/19/08  PROVIDER,ONE 
7. Hypertension, Onset 00/00/05                       11/09/08  PROVIDER,ONE 
 
 b) CURRENT SIGNIFICANT PAIN PROBLEMS: None
 
 c) NUTRITION ASSESSMENT: obese, diabetic, otherwise ok

 d) CURRENT VA-PRESCRIBED MEDICATIONS: 
Active Outpatient Medications (excluding Supplies):
 
     Pending Outpatient Medications                         Status
=========================================================================
1)   ASPIRIN 81MG EC TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     PENDING
       DAY
2)   CALCIUM CARBONATE 1.25GM (CA 500MG) TAB TAKE 500 MG    PENDING
       BY MOUTH THREE TIMES A DAY
3)   CHLORTHALIDONE 25MG TAB TAKE 12.5 MG  BY MOUTH EVERY   PENDING
       DAY
4)   ERGOCALCIFEROL 1000 UNIT CAP TAKE 1000 UNITS BY MOUTH  PENDING
       EVERY DAY
5)   GLYBURIDE 2.5MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     PENDING
       DAY
6)   LEVOTHYROXINE NA (SYNTHROID) 0.125MG TAB TAKE ONE      PENDING
       TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY
7)   LISINOPRIL 20MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY     PENDING
       DAY
8)   SIMVASTATIN 80MG TAB TAKE ONE TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY    PENDING
       EVENING
9)   VENLAFAXINE HCL 37.5MG TAB TAKE TWO TABLETS BY MOUTH   PENDING
       TWICE A DAY
 MEDICATION RECONCILIATION: 
()The medication list above was reviewed with the patient at today's
  visit.  I have indicated discrepancies under each medication that 
  is not being taken as prescribed.  Medication orders, including any
  additions or discontinuations, have been updated as appropriate,
  and the patient now has an accurate medication list.
()No medications were started, stopped, or changed at this visit.
()Medications were prescribed or changed at this visit. However, the
  medications were prescribed for a short period of time and/or the 
  medication changes were temporary.

 e) CURRENT NON-VA MEDICATIONS: 
    None 
 f) CURRENT NICOTINE AND CAFFEINE USE: 
    quit tobacco approx 2006

 g) FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY diabetes, hyperlipidemia

 h) WOMEN: LAST MENTSTRAL CYCLE, CONTRACEPTION, HISTORY OF PREGNANCY 
post-menopausal, approx 2011


ALLERGIES AND ADVERSE DRUG REACTIONS: 
METFORMIN, CITALOPRAM, FLUOXETINE

LAST VITAL SIGN 
   Temperature:  98.7 F [37.1 C] (02/28/2013 07:55) 
Blood Pressure:  135/82 (07/01/2013 11:36)

          Pain:  0 (02/28/2013 07:55)

   Details:

 
DESCRIPTIVE MENTAL STATUS EXAM:
-------------------------------
ORIENTATION AND CONSCIOUSNESS:
  alert and attentive
APPEARANCE AND BEHAVIOR:
  cooperative and reasonable
  grooming appropriate
SPEECH:
  normal rate/rhythm

MOOD AND AFFECT:
  affect flat
  mood depressed
  details: 
    patient still expresses depression/sadnesss.  mildly flat affect
PERCEPTUAL DISTURBANCE (hallucinations, illusions):
  none
THOUGHT PROCESS AND ASSOCIATION:
  normal, coherent
THOUGHT CONTENT (delusions, obsessions etc.):
  no unusual thought content
SUICIDAL OR VIOLENT IDEATION:
  suicidal ideation passive without plan, contracts for safety
  Other:  completed safety plan 2/27/13
INSIGHT:
  good
JUDGMENT: 
  good
MEMORY: 
  intact
FUND OF KNOWLEDGE:   Average
MINI MENTAL STATE EXAM:
-----------------------
 
SCORE QUESTIONS:
   4   What is: year, season, date, day, month. 
   4   What is: state, county, city, hospital, floor. 
   3   Name 3 objects: 1 sec to say each, then ask pt all 3 
objects after you have said them. 
   4   Serial 7's or "world" backwards.  Stop after 5 answers. 
   3   Ask for the 3 objects repeated in question 3. 
   2   Name a pencil and a watch (2 points)
   2   Repeat "No ifs, ands or buts" 
   3   Follow 3 stage command: "Take this piece of paper in your 
right hand, fold it in half, and put it on the floor" (1 point for each 
instruction followed correctly, max score = 3)
   2   Read and obey written command, "CLOSE YOUR EYES" 
   2   Write a sentence 
   2   Copy intersecting pentagons 
                      Total Score (max=30):30
SUMMARY AND FORMULATION:
------------------------

                      INITIAL DSM-IV DIAGNOSIS:
Axis I Clinical Disorder:
  Depressive Disorder:  Major Depression
  Marital Problems
Axis II Personality Disorders/Traits:
  None
Axis III Current Medical Conditions:  See Medical History above
Axis IV Current Psychosocial Stressors:
 social environment, job related problems
 
Axis V GAF Score (current level of functioning): 

Last GAF Score: 65


PLAN:
1.  MEDICATIONS:
Continue current psychiatric medications. 

Discussed options including no changes.  Change current psychiatric 
medications: Reviewed SE, risks, and possible benefits of tx with maximum dose 
of venlafaxine (225mg/day.) Due to previous ADRs with other antidepressants, 
patient prefers to try the increased dose instead of adding a 2nd 
antidepressant.  Increased risk of suicidal thoughts discussed, and the 
importance of following her safety plan and avoiding social isolation.
She has decisional capacity, verbalized an understanding of, 
and agreement with this plan. A medication handout will be provided 
when she receives the medication from the pharmacy.

2.  LABS/OTHER TESTS: lipid panel in 3 months

3.  REFERRALS: weekly group therapy

4.  FOLLOW-UP: RTC in 6 weeks/months, sooner PRN.

Time with patient: 90 Min
Long Term goals decreased phq9, improved coping skills, improved mood and 
affect.

Anticipated Duration:3-6 Months
